standard_metadata.standard_description: Find all factor pairs for a whole number in the range 1–100. Recognize that a whole number is a multiple of each of its factors. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1–100 is a multiple of a given one-digit number. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1–100 is prime or composite.

question.content: We know $9 \times 2 = 18$.  **So, which of the following statements are also true?**

hints.content: When both factors are whole numbers, then:  $\blueD{\text{factor}} \times \blueD{\text{factor}} = \maroonD{\text{multiple}}$

$\blueD9 \times \blueD2 = \maroonD{18}$    So,   - $\blueD9$ and $\blueD2$ are $\blueD{\text{factors}}$ of $\maroonD{18}$. - $\maroonD{18}$ is a $\maroonD{\text{multiple}}$ of $\blueD9$ and $\blueD2$.
The true statements are:  - $\blueD9$ is a factor of $\maroonD{18}$.   - $\maroonD{18}$ is a multiple of $\blueD2$.

question.content: We know $7 \times 8 = 56$.  **So, which of the following statements are also true?**

hints.content: When both factors are whole numbers, then:  $\blueD{\text{factor}} \times \blueD{\text{factor}} = \maroonD{\text{multiple}}$
$\blueD7 \times \blueD8 = \maroonD{56}$  So,  - $\blueD7$ and $\blueD8$ are $\blueD{\text{factors}}$ of $\maroonD{56}$. - $\maroonD{56}$ is a $\maroonD{\text{multiple}}$ of $\blueD7$ and $\blueD8$.
The true statements are:  - $\blueD7$ is a factor of $\maroonD{56}$.  - $\blueD8$ is a factor of $\maroonD{56}$.

The true statements are:  - $\blueD5$ is a factor of $\maroonD{15}$.  - $\maroonD{15}$ is a multiple of $\blueD5$.

$\blueD2 \times \blueD6 = \maroonD{12}$  So,  - $\blueD2$ and $\blueD6$ are $\blueD{\text{factors}}$ of $\maroonD{12}$. - $\maroonD{12}$ is a $\maroonD{\text{multiple}}$ of $\blueD2$ and $\blueD6$.
The true statements are:  - $\maroonD{12}$ is a multiple of $\blueD2$. - $\maroonD{12}$ is a multiple of $\blueD6$.

$\blueD8 \times \blueD5 = \maroonD{40}$  So,  - $\blueD8$ and $\blueD5$ are $\blueD{\text{factors}}$ of $\maroonD{40}$. - $\maroonD{40}$ is a $\maroonD{\text{multiple}}$ of $\blueD8$ and $\blueD5$.
The true statements are:  - $\blueD5$ is a factor of $\maroonD{40}$. - $\blueD8$ is a factor of $\maroonD{40}$.

question.content: **What set of numbers are shaded on the hundred chart?**

hints.content: When both factors are whole numbers, then:  $\blueE{\text{factor}} \times \blueE{\text{factor}} = \maroonD{\text{multiple}}$

###Factors of $24$  $\begin{align} \blueE{1} \times \blueE{24} &= \maroonD{24}\\\\ \blueE{2} \times \blueE{12} &= \maroonD{24}\\\\ \blueE{3} \times \blueE{8} &= \maroonD{24}\\\\ \blueE{4} \times \blueE{6} &= \maroonD{24} \end{align}$  All of the shaded numbers in the table are factors of $\maroonD{24}$.
The shaded numbers on the hundred chart are only the factors of $24$.

question.content: **What set of numbers are shaded on the hundred chart?**

hints.content: When both factors are whole numbers, then:  $\blueE{\text{factor}} \times \blueE{\text{factor}} = \maroonD{\text{multiple}}$

###Factors of $45$  $\begin{align} \blueE{1} \times \blueE{45} &= \maroonD{45}\\\\ \blueE{3} \times \blueE{15} &= \maroonD{45}\\\\ \blueE{5} \times \blueE{9} &= \maroonD{45}\\\\ \end{align}$  All of the shaded numbers in the table are factors of $\maroonD{45}$.
The shaded numbers on the hundred chart are only the factors of $45$.

question.content: **What set of numbers are shaded on the hundred chart?**

hints.content: When both factors are whole numbers, then:  $\blueE{\text{factor}} \times \blueE{\text{factor}} = \maroonD{\text{multiple}}$

###Factors of $53$  $\begin{align} \blueE{1} \times \blueE{53} &= \maroonD{53} \end{align}$  All of the shaded numbers in the table are factors of $\maroonD{53}$.  There's a special name for numbers with exactly two factors! The number $\maroonD{53}$ is **prime**.
The shaded numbers on the hundred chart are only the factors of $53$.

question.content: **What set of numbers are shaded on the hundred chart?**

hints.content: When both factors are whole numbers, then:  $\blueE{\text{factor}} \times \blueE{\text{factor}} = \maroonD{\text{multiple}}$

###Factors of $36$  $\begin{align} \blueE{1} \times \blueE{36} &= \maroonD{36}\\\\ \blueE{2} \times \blueE{18} &= \maroonD{36}\\\\ \blueE{3} \times \blueE{12} &= \maroonD{36}\\\\ \blueE{4} \times \blueE{9} &= \maroonD{36}\\\\ \blueE{6} \times \blueE{6} &= \maroonD{36} \end{align}$  All of the shaded numbers in the table are factors of $\maroonD{36}$.
The shaded numbers on the hundred chart are only the factors of $36$.

question.content: **What set of numbers are shaded on the hundred chart?**

hints.content: When both factors are whole numbers, then:  $\blueE{\text{factor}} \times \blueE{\text{factor}} = \maroonD{\text{multiple}}$

###Multiples of $6$  $\begin{align} \blueE{6} \times \blueE{1} &= \maroonD{6}\\\\ \blueE{6} \times \blueE{2} &= \maroonD{12}\\\\ \blueE{6} \times \blueE{3} &= \maroonD{18}\\\\ \blueE{6} \times \blueE{4} &= \maroonD{24}\\\\ \blueE{6} \times \blueE{5} &= \maroonD{30}\\\\ \blueE{6} \times \blueE{6} &= \maroonD{36}\\\\ \blueE{6} \times \blueE{7} &= \maroonD{42}\\\\ \blueE{6} \times \blueE{8} &= \maroonD{48}\\\\ \blueE{6} \times \blueE{9} &= \maroonD{54}\\\\ \blueE{6} \times \blueE{10} &= \maroonD{60}\\\\ \blueE{6} \times \blueE{11} &= \maroonD{66}\\\\ \blueE{6} \times \blueE{12} &= \maroonD{72}\\\\ \blueE{6} \times \blueE{13} &= \maroonD{78}\\\\ \blueE{6} \times \blueE{14} &= \maroonD{84}\\\\ \blueE{6} \times \blueE{15} &= \maroonD{90}\\\\ \blueE{6} \times \blueE{16} &= \maroonD{96} \end{align}$  All of the shaded numbers in the table are multiples of $\blueE{6}$. Every multiple of $6$ between $1$ and $100$ is shaded.
The shaded numbers on the hundred chart are only the multiples of $6$.

question.content: **What set of numbers are shaded on the hundred chart?**

hints.content: When both factors are whole numbers, then:  $\blueE{\text{factor}} \times \blueE{\text{factor}} = \maroonD{\text{multiple}}$

###Multiples of $7$  $\begin{align} \blueE{7} \times \blueE{1} &= \maroonD{7}\\\\ \blueE{7} \times \blueE{2} &= \maroonD{14}\\\\ \blueE{7} \times \blueE{3} &= \maroonD{21}\\\\ \blueE{7} \times \blueE{4} &= \maroonD{28}\\\\ \blueE{7} \times \blueE{5} &= \maroonD{35}\\\\ \blueE{7} \times \blueE{6} &= \maroonD{42}\\\\ \blueE{7} \times \blueE{7} &= \maroonD{49}\\\\ \blueE{7} \times \blueE{8} &= \maroonD{56}\\\\ \blueE{7} \times \blueE{9} &= \maroonD{63}\\\\ \blueE{7} \times \blueE{10} &= \maroonD{70}\\\\ \blueE{7} \times \blueE{11} &= \maroonD{77}\\\\ \blueE{7} \times \blueE{12} &= \maroonD{84}\\\\ \blueE{7} \times \blueE{13} &= \maroonD{91}\\\\ \blueE{7} \times \blueE{14} &= \maroonD{98} \end{align}$  All of the shaded numbers in the table are multiples of $\blueE{7}$. Every multiple of $7$ between $1$ and $100$ is shaded.
The shaded numbers on the hundred chart are only the multiples of $7$.

hints.content: When both factors are whole numbers, then:  $\blueE{\text{factor}} \times \blueE{\text{factor}} = \maroonD{\text{multiple}}$

###Multiples of $8$  $\begin{align} \blueE{8} \times \blueE{1} &= \maroonD{8}\\\\ \blueE{8} \times \blueE{2} &= \maroonD{16}\\\\ \blueE{8} \times \blueE{3} &= \maroonD{24}\\\\ \blueE{8} \times \blueE{4} &= \maroonD{32}\\\\ \blueE{8} \times \blueE{5} &= \maroonD{40}\\\\ \blueE{8} \times \blueE{6} &= \maroonD{48}\\\\ \blueE{8} \times \blueE{7} &= \maroonD{56}\\\\ \blueE{8} \times \blueE{8} &= \maroonD{64}\\\\ \blueE{8} \times \blueE{9} &= \maroonD{72}\\\\ \blueE{8} \times \blueE{10} &= \maroonD{80}\\\\ \blueE{8} \times \blueE{11} &= \maroonD{88}\\\\ \blueE{8} \times \blueE{12} &= \maroonD{96} \end{align}$  All of the shaded numbers in the table are multiples of $\blueE{8}$. Every multiple of $8$ between $1$ and $100$ is shaded.
The shaded numbers on the hundred chart are only the multiples of $8$.

question.content: Laura tried to shade all the multiples of $9$ on the hundred chart, but she made a mistake.    **What mistake did Laura make?**

options.content: Laura shaded the factors instead of the multiples of $9$.
Laura shaded $9$, but multiples are always greater than the number.
Laura shaded three multiples of $9$, but she left out some.

hints.content: When both factors are whole numbers, then:  $\blueE{\text{factor}} \times \blueE{\text{factor}} = \maroonD{\text{multiple}}$

$\begin{align} \blueE{9} \times \blueE{1} &= \maroonD{9}\\\\ \blueE{9} \times \blueE{2} &= \maroonD{18}\\\\ \blueE{9} \times \blueE{3} &= \maroonD{27}\\\\ \blueE{9} \times \blueE{4} &= \maroonD{36} \end{align}$  So some multiples of $\blueE{9}$ are $\maroonD{9}$, $\maroonD{18}$, $\maroonD{27}$, and $\maroonD{36}$.  Laura only shaded one of those numbers, so she is not correct.
$\begin{align} \blueE{1} \times \blueE{9} &= \maroonD{9}\\\\ \blueE{3} \times \blueE{3} &= \maroonD{9} \end{align}$  So the factors of $\maroonD{9}$ are $\blueE{1}$, $\blueE{3}$, and $\blueE{9}$.
Laura shaded the factors instead of the multiples of $9$.

question.content: Kieran tried to shade all the multiples of $3$ on the hundred chart, but he made a mistake.    **What mistake did Kieran make?**

options.content: Kieran shaded the factors instead of the multiples of $3$.
Kieran shaded the multiples of $6$ instead of the multiples of $3$.
Kieran shaded the multiples of $9$ instead of the multiples of $3$.

hints.content: When both factors are whole numbers, then:  $\blueE{\text{factor}} \times \blueE{\text{factor}} = \maroonD{\text{multiple}}$

$\begin{align} \blueE{3} \times \blueE{1} &= \maroonD{3}\\\\ \blueE{3} \times \blueE{2} &= \maroonD{6}\\\\ \blueE{3} \times \blueE{3} &= \maroonD{9}\\\\ \blueE{3} \times \blueE{4} &= \maroonD{12}\\\\ \blueE{3} \times \blueE{6} &= \maroonD{15}\\\\ \blueE{3} \times \blueE{8} &= \maroonD{18} \end{align}$  So some multiples of $\blueE{3}$ are $\maroonD{3}$, $\maroonD{6}$, $\maroonD{9}$, $\maroonD{12}$, $\maroonD{15}$, and $\maroonD{18}$.  Kieran only shaded some of those numbers. So he is not correct.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

$\begin{align} \blueE{9} \times \blueE{1} &= \maroonD{9}\\\\ \blueE{9} \times \blueE{2} &= \maroonD{18}\\\\ \blueE{9} \times \blueE{3} &= \maroonD{27}\\\\ \blueE{9} \times \blueE{4} &= \maroonD{36} \\\\ \blueE{9} \times \blueE{5} &= \maroonD{45}\\\\ \blueE{9} \times \blueE{6} &= \maroonD{54}\\\\ \blueE{9} \times \blueE{7} &= \maroonD{63}\\\\ \blueE{9} \times \blueE{8} &= \maroonD{72}\\\\ \blueE{9} \times \blueE{9} &= \maroonD{81} \\\\ \blueE{9} \times \blueE{10} &= \maroonD{90}\\\\ \blueE{9} \times \blueE{11} &= \maroonD{99} \end{align}$  So the multiples of $\blueE{9}$ that are on a hundred chart are $\maroonD{9}$, $\maroonD{18}$, $\maroonD{27}$, $\maroonD{36}$, $\maroonD{45}$, $\maroonD{54}$, $\maroonD{63}$, $\maroonD{72}$, $\maroonD{81}$, $\maroonD{90}$, and $\maroonD{99}$.
Kieran shaded the multiples of $9$ instead of the multiples of $3$.

question.content: Stef tried to shade all the multiples of $5$ on the hundred chart, but he made a mistake.    **What mistake did Stef make?**

options.content: Stef shaded the factors instead of the multiples of $5$.
Stef shaded the multiples of $10$ instead of the multiples of $5$.

hints.content: When both factors are whole numbers, then:  $\blueE{\text{factor}} \times \blueE{\text{factor}} = \maroonD{\text{multiple}}$

$\begin{align} \blueE{5} \times \blueE{1} &= \maroonD{5}\\\\ \blueE{5} \times \blueE{2} &= \maroonD{10}\\\\ \blueE{5} \times \blueE{3} &= \maroonD{15}\\\\ \blueE{5} \times \blueE{4} &= \maroonD{20} \end{align}$  So some multiples of $\blueE{5}$ are $\maroonD{5}$, $\maroonD{10}$, $\maroonD{15}$, and $\maroonD{20}$.  Stef forgot to shade $5$, so he is not correct.
Stef didn't shade $5$.

question.content: Francie tried to shade all the multiples of $8$ on the hundred chart, but she made a mistake.    **What mistake did Francie make?**

options.content: Francie shaded the factors instead of the multiples of $8$.
Francie shaded $8$, but multiples are always greater than the number.
Francie shaded the multiples of $4$ instead of the multiples of $8$.

hints.content: When both factors are whole numbers, then:  $\blueE{\text{factor}} \times \blueE{\text{factor}} = \maroonD{\text{multiple}}$

$\begin{align} \blueE{8} \times \blueE{1} &= \maroonD{8}\\\\ \blueE{8} \times \blueE{2} &= \maroonD{16}\\\\ \blueE{8} \times \blueE{3} &= \maroonD{24}\\\\ \blueE{8} \times \blueE{4} &= \maroonD{32} \end{align}$  So some multiples of $\blueE{8}$ are $\maroonD{8}$, $\maroonD{16}$, $\maroonD{24}$, and $\maroonD{32}$.  Francie only shaded one of those numbers, so she is not correct.

$\begin{align} \blueE{1} \times \blueE{8} &= \maroonD{8}\\\\ \blueE{2} \times \blueE{4} &= \maroonD{8} \end{align}$  So the factors of $\maroonD{8}$ are $\blueE{1}$, $\blueE{2}$, $\blueE{4}$, and $\blueE{8}$.
Francie shaded the factors instead of the multiples of $8$.

question.content: Carlos tried to shade all the factors of $30$ on the hundred chart, but he made a mistake.    **What mistake did Carlos make?**

options.content: Carlos shaded the multiples instead of the factors of $30$.
Carlos shaded $15$, but $15$ is a multiple of $5$, so it cannot be a factor.
Carlos shaded four factors of $30$, but he left out some.

hints.content: When both factors are whole numbers, then:  $\blueE{\text{factor}} \times \blueE{\text{factor}} = \maroonD{\text{multiple}}$

$\begin{align} \blueE{1} \times \blueE{30} &= \maroonD{30}\\\\ \blueE{2} \times \blueE{15} &= \maroonD{30}\\\\ \blueE{3} \times \blueE{10} &= \maroonD{30}\\\\ \blueE{5} \times \blueE{6} &= \maroonD{30} \end{align}$  So the factors of $\maroonD{30}$ are $\blueE{1}$, $\blueE{2}$, $\blueE{3}$, $\blueE{5}$, $\blueE{6}$, $\blueE{10}$, $\blueE{15}$, and $\blueE{30}$.  Carlos only shaded four of those numbers, so he is not correct.
Carlos shaded four factors of $30$, but he left out some.

question.content: Scarlett tried to shade all the factors of $15$ on the hundred chart, but she made a mistake.    **What mistake did Scarlett make?**

options.content: Scarlett shaded the multiples instead of the factors of $15$.
Scarlett shaded $15$, but factors are always less than the number.
Scarlett shaded the factors of $5$ instead of the factors of $15$.

hints.content: When both factors are whole numbers, then:  $\blueE{\text{factor}} \times \blueE{\text{factor}} = \maroonD{\text{multiple}}$

$\begin{align} \blueE{1} \times \blueE{15} &= \maroonD{15}\\\\ \blueE{3} \times \blueE{5} &= \maroonD{15}\\\\ \end{align}$  So the factors of $\maroonD{15}$ are $\blueE{1}$, $\blueE{3}$, $\blueE{5}$, and $\blueE{15}$.  Scarlett only shaded one of those numbers, so she is not correct.

$\begin{align} \blueE{15} \times \blueE{1} &= \maroonD{15}\\\\ \blueE{15} \times \blueE{2} &= \maroonD{30}\\\\ \blueE{15} \times \blueE{3} &= \maroonD{45}\\\\ \blueE{15} \times \blueE{4} &= \maroonD{60}\\\\ \blueE{15} \times \blueE{5} &= \maroonD{75}\\\\ \blueE{15} \times \blueE{6} &= \maroonD{90}\\\\ \blueE{15} \times \blueE{7} &= \maroonD{105} \end{align}$  So the multiples of $\blueD{15}$ that are on a hundred chart are $\maroonD{15}$, $\maroonD{30}$, $\maroonD{45}$, $\maroonD{60}$, $\maroonD{75}$, and $\maroonD{90}$.
Scarlett shaded the multiples instead of the factors of $15$.

question.content: Elijah tried to shade all the factors of $50$ on the hundred chart, but he made a mistake.    **What mistake did Elijah make?**

options.content: Elijah shaded the multiples instead of the factors of $50$.
Elijah shaded three numbers, but there are always an even number of factors.
Elijah only shaded the factors of $25$ instead of all of the factors of $50$.

hints.content: When both factors are whole numbers, then:  $\blueE{\text{factor}} \times \blueE{\text{factor}} = \maroonD{\text{multiple}}$

$\begin{align} \blueE{1} \times \blueE{50} &= \maroonD{50}\\\\ \blueE{2} \times \blueE{25} &= \maroonD{50}\\\\ \blueE{5} \times \blueE{10} &= \maroonD{50} \end{align}$  So the factors of $\maroonD{50}$ are $\blueE{1}$, $\blueE{2}$, $\blueE{5}$, $\blueE{10}$, $\blueE{25}$, and $\blueE{50}$.  Elijah only shaded three of those numbers, so he is not correct.

$\begin{align} \blueE{1} \times \blueE{25} &= \maroonD{25}\\\\ \blueE{5} \times \blueE{5} &= \maroonD{25} \end{align}$  So the factors of $\maroonD{25}$ are $\blueE{1}$, $\blueE{5}$, and $\blueE{25}$.
Elijah only shaded the factors of $25$ instead of all of the factors of $50$.
